poem:
**Ode to the New Mother**

The memory of pain  
nestles in morning light—  
a tender burden,  
unlike the consultant's absence,  
unlike the proffered shield.  
Still, you bore the marks,  
silent as the dawn,  
carving love's first latches,  
raw and unyielding,  
until milk became the language  
between you and history.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Painful memories of the struggle to breastfeed | Letters Reading Niamh Campbell’s article on breastfeeding brought back painful memories for me (‘Like a cheese grater raking across my nipple’: why I kept trying to breastfeed for so long, 3 September). Nearly 43 years ago, I too found breastfeeding agonisingly painful. Unlike her, I never had access to a lactation consultant, and the only advice I was offered by health professionals was to wear a nipple". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
